references: Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.

Thompson, B. C., P. J. Crist, J. S. Prior-Magee, R. A. Deitner, D. L. Garber, and M. A. Hughes. 1996. Gap analysis of biological diversity conservation in New Mexico using geographic information systems Research Completion Report, New Mexico Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit, Las Cruces, NM.
Frey, J. K. 2004. Taxonomy and distribution of the mammals of New Mexico: an annotated checklist Occasional Papers, Museum, Texas Tech University 240:1-32
Best, T.L., J.L. Bartig, and S.L. Burt. 1992. Tamias canipes. The American Society of Mammalogists Mammalian Species No. 411, pp. 1-5.
habitat_description:
Southwest/Great Plains:
T. canipes is found in pinyon-juniper, aspen, spruce-fir, limber pine, Douglas-fir, redberry juniper, scrub oak, chinkapin oak, and buckthorn (Ramnus purshiana), snakeweed, wolly groundsel, purple dahlia, cholla cactus, yucca, streptanthus, fourwing saltbush, rattail cactus, red salvia, bitterweed, borage, erigeron, blue curls, clammy weed, bladderpod, tansy mustard, verbena, barberry, saltcedar, cattail, sedges, muhly, fescue, gramma and buffalograss, cottonwood, alder, willow, Apache plume and mesquite (Best et al. 1992, Thompson et al. 1996). The species is more closely associated with shrubby oaks in September (Best et al. 1992).  It occurs in marsh, scrub-grassland, juniper savannah, lava fields near Carrizozo, NM, plains and Great Basin swamp and riparian scrub (Best et al. 1992, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  PNV - Engelmann's spruce, Douglas-fir - white fir (Thompson et al. 1996).  Species is most numerous in coniferous forest with fallen logs (Thompson et al. 1996).  It frequents dense stands of mixed timber (oaks, pines, firs) where rock crevices offer retreat and on brushy hillsides (Thompson et al. 1996).  It occupies approximately the same range of habitat as T. quadrivittatus (Thompson et al. 1996).  In the absence of T. dorsalis, it occurs to the lower edge of the woodland and even to grassland (Best et al. 1992).  T. canipes eats sunflower seeds, gooseberries, currants, and mushrooms (Best et al. 1992).  The species hibernates in winter or keeps food in dens and caches (Best et al. 1992).  Elevation is 1,600-3,600m (Best et al. 1992, NatureServe 2002). The species occurs in the Carrizozo lava field and in the mountains of central and southeast New Mexico (Findley et al. 1975, Frey 2004). Occurs in the Jicarilla Mountains, Guadalupe mountains, Capitan Mountains, Gallinas Mountains, Sacramento Mountains, White Mountains.
